title: Federal Cyber Directive Spotlights Aging Computer Systems
summary: Outdated equipment, talent shortages have complicated efforts to address vulnerabilities. Many of the cybersecurity gaps outlined in a new White House directive that calls on federal agencies to patch hundreds of online vulnerabilities stem from the government's aging computer systems, current and former federal tech chiefs, lawmakers and industry analysts say.

title: Canada Strips Military of Powers to Investigate Sexual Misconduct
summary: Defense minister says all investigations, prosecutions of sexual offenses in military to be handled by civilian law enforcement. OTTAWA-Canada on Thursday said all allegations of sexual misconduct within the country's armed forces would now be investigated and prosecuted by civilian authorities, citing skepticism among soldiers and the public about the military's ability to police itself.

title: Peloton's Sprain Turns Into a Tear
summary: Slashed forecast shows that demand is taking a serious breather for the one-time star of connected fitness. Slimming down in three months is quite an accomplishment in fitness. Unless you're Peloton , that is.

title: Biden Vaccine Mandate Poses New Test for Agency Enforcing It
summary: Occupational Safety and Health Administration has struggled during Covid-19 pandemic to deploy staff for workplace inspections. The enforcement of President Biden's private-sector vaccine mandate will in large measure come down to the employees themselves, as the government agency whose mission is to improve workplace safety works to play a bigger role in defeating the pandemic.

title: Biden Says Payments to Separated Families Are 'Not Gonna Happen'
summary: President dismisses reports of DOJ talks to settle suits by families separated while illegally crossing border with payments of $450,000 a person. WASHINGTON-President Biden said the U.S. wasn't going to pay immigrant families who were separated at the Mexico border during the Trump administration, throwing into doubt settlements the Justice Department has been negotiating to resolve legal claims by the families.

title: OSHA's Vaccine Mandate Overkill
summary: The 490-page Biden rule is unnecessary and needlessly divisive.. Covid cases and hospitalization have blessedly plunged since the summer Delta surge as more Americans have been vaccinated or acquired natural immunity. Yet the Biden Administration is still fighting the last virus war, and on Thursday rolled out its worker vaccine mandate, which will likely do more harm than good.

title: The $3.98 Trillion Trojan Horse
summary: Penn Wharton says the real cost is more than twice what Pelosi says.. The White House and House leaders are going all out to sell their monstrosity of a budget bill, which they claim will cost $1.75 trillion over 10 years. The Treasury even rolled out an estimate claiming it will reduce the federal deficit. Anyone who believes this probably responds to email pitches from Nigeria.

title: Pelosi's SALT Scheme
summary: House Democrats raise a deduction that goes mainly to high-tax states.. Don't Democrats want to raise taxes on the rich? We seem to recall this-correct us if we're wrong-but then how are they going to explain their expansion of the state-and-local tax deduction for largely affluent taxpayers in mainly Democratic states?

title: Airbnb Posts Record Results After Busy Summer Travel Season
summary: Home-sharing app sees a surge in bookings for this year's Thanksgiving holiday period. Airbnb Inc. posted record revenue in the third quarter, punctuating the home-sharing company's rebound from the collapse in bookings during the early days of the pandemic.

title: Durham and the Clinton Dossier
summary: A new indictment continues the slow unraveling of a 2016 political scandal.. The nation argued for five years over the infamous "Steele dossier," the document on which the Federal Bureau of Investigation relied to investigate Donald Trump's 2016 campaign. It should have been called the Clinton dossier.

title: Democracy and the Turnout Boom
summary: Voting numbers negate partisan prophecies of self-government's doom.. After the Senate failed to pass legislation Wednesday that would empower the federal government to intervene more aggressively in state voting rules, Majority Leader Chuck Schumer chided Republicans for failing "to acknowledge that our country faces a serious threat to democracy."

title: Venture Capitalist Says He Lacked Information but Still Invested
summary: Holmes said lack of details was to protect proprietary technology from theft. SAN JOSE, Calif.-Venture capitalist Chris Lucas invested in Theranos Inc. despite having less information about the startup than he was accustomed to getting as part of his decision-making process.

title: News Corp Profit Surges on Gains Across Divisions
summary: Media company's revenue grew 18% thanks to improvements at all its divisions. News Corp said quarterly profit rose nearly sixfold, driven by strong growth at its digital real-estate and book-publishing businesses as well as at Wall Street Journal parent Dow Jones & Co.

title: 'American Comics' Review: Panels, Strips & Graphic Novels
summary: From political cartoons to the Sunday funnies, from D.C. and Marvel to Zap and 'Maus,' the evolution of an all-American art form.. In 1976 Marvel Comics published "Howard the Duck," starring a foul-mouthed, beak-billed alien stranded on earth among "talking hairless apes." Sadly, Steve Gerber's metafictional, existentialist romp was largely dismissed as a "funny animal" comic by those who associated comics with subliterate escapism. The medium itself has long been the ugly duckling of American culture, a stealth art form whose secret, swanlike identity (more bird than plane) has been accorded widespread acclaim only in the past few decades. Comic strips, which emerged at the turn of the 20th century, were at least in respectable newspapers. This could not be said for their down-market cousin, the floppy comic "book" that began littering playgrounds and treehouses in the 1930s.

title: Taiwan Won't Capitulate to China
summary: Changes in military structure will help us meet any challenge.. The Taiwan Strait is attracting a great deal of global attention, mainly because the international community is alarmed by the rise of China. China's People's Liberation Army is constantly expanding its ability to project force in the Indo-Pacific region, and its activities in the East and South China seas have unsettled many. China has harassed Taiwan through "gray zone" activities around the Taiwan Strait.

title: Pinterest's Mood Swings
summary: Between users, suitors and investors, sentiment toward the image-sharing company right now is unsettled. Pinterest had lost over 50% of its market value from February highs heading into Thursday's earnings report, but investors now seem to think the company's shares have finally bottomed. They will have to hope its user base has, too.

title: The Big New Jersey Election Upset: A Truck Driver Beats Steve Sweeney
summary: Republican on a shoestring campaign budget defeats longtime political power broker. Ed Durr, a truck driver for Raymour & Flanigan who defeated New Jersey political powerhouse Steve Sweeney, said of all Tuesday's election-upset victories, he was as surprised as anybody about his own.

title: California Is the Supply Chain's Weakest Link
summary: Environmental and antibusiness regulations in the deep blue state are backing up port traffic.. The backup of container ships at the Long Beach and Los Angeles ports has grown in recent weeks despite President Biden's intervention to get terminal operators to move goods 24/7. The ports said last week they would fine shipping companies that let containers sit at terminals too long. But consumers will end up paying the fines, and shippers aren't to blame for the delays. Who is?

title: Nuclear Power Is the Best Climate-Change Solution by Far
summary: Its total greenhouse-gas emissions are 1/700th those of coal-and one-fourth those of solar.. Politics seems to have become inimical to critical thinking, and nowhere is this more obvious than climate change. Politicians peddle apocalypse and demand that Americans accept skyrocketing gasoline and home heating costs, rolling blackouts and brownouts, endless subsidies for uneconomic vehicles and power generation, and on and on.

title: Russia Is Biden's Next Foreign-Policy Test
summary: So far he hasn't deterred Putin from massing troops at the Ukrainian border.. While President Biden has been distracted by a climate-change conference and sagging approval at home, President Vladimir Putin is building up Russian forces along the Ukrainian border. The Biden administration must respond to this provocation and do what President Obama didn't-deter Russian aggression against its Western neighbor-before it's too late.

title: Voters Give Democrats a Woke-Up Call
summary: Will the party recognize its mistake in embracing extremism? Will the GOP prove worthy of its wins?. 'Took my first DC trip yesterday since pre-COVID. Union Station mostly deserted, hardly any stores/restaurants open. 2 homeless guys hanging out & begging in the seating area at Sbarro's. Real 'decline of the republic' vibe in the building. The election results didn't surprise me."-the Week columnist Damon Linker on Twitter Wednesday

title: Kellogg Faces Growing Costs as Labor Strike, Supply Snags Persist
summary: Cereal maker raises sales forecast as quarterly net sales beat estimates. A monthlong strike at Kellogg Co. is raising the cereal company's costs as it contends with continuing inflation and supply-chain disruptions.

title: Eric Adams Says Pay Me in Bitcoin
summary: Next New York City mayor wants his first three paychecks in the form of the cryptocurrency. Eric Adams, the next mayor of New York, wants to turn the city into the crypto capital of the world.

title: 'Flash in the Pan': The Long Life of a Fleeting Flintlock Failure
summary: An expression that sounds like it comes from the kitchen or the Gold Rush has its origins in early musketry. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: IBM Spinoff Kyndryl Starts Quest for Growth
summary: The company is hoping to help customers manage their growing forays into the cloud. International Business Machines Corp. completed the spinoff of its $19 billion information technology services business on Wednesday, betting that independence will make it easier to reverse a decline in revenue.

title: AT&T, Verizon to Delay 5G Rollout Over FAA's Airliner Safety Concerns
summary: Wireless carriers postpone planned Dec. 5 launch of new spectrum to address concerns about potential interference with cockpit safety systems. AT&T Inc. and Verizon Communications Inc. agreed to delay their planned Dec. 5 rollout of a new 5G frequency band so they can work with the Federal Aviation Administration to address concerns about potential interference with key cockpit safety systems.

title: NBA Opens Investigation Into Phoenix Suns After Toxic Workplace Allegations
summary: A report from ESPN said that team owner Robert Sarver used a racial slur and fostered a misogynistic environment. Sarver denied the allegations.. The NBA opened an investigation into the Phoenix Suns on Thursday in response to a new report containing allegations of a toxic workplace cultivated by team owner Robert Sarver, the league said.

title: Peloton's Sales Lose Speed as Fewer People Work Out at Home
summary: Shares plunge after fitness machine maker cuts annual targets for revenue and subscribers. Peloton Interactive Inc. is slowing down.

title: Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin Loses Suit Over NASA Moon Lander
summary: Federal judge dismisses Blue Origin's complaint about NASA's contract being awarded solely to Elon Musk's SpaceX. A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit from the space company founded by Jeff Bezos over a NASA contract, a setback for Blue Origin's effort to win work developing a moon lander.

title: MIT Cancels What Most Call Common Sense
summary: Prof. Dorian Abbot expresses the opinions of many with a level of confidence that has been missing.. Thank you for publishing Dorian Abbot's "The Views That Made Me Persona Non Grata at MIT" (op-ed, Oct. 30). It reflects the opinion of so many who have felt their voices suppressed for so long-whether at meetings for the local planning commission, school board, church or soccer-club selection. Mr. Abbot instills a level of confidence sorely missing in our public discourse.

title: Don't Let Comrade Omarova Regulate the Banks
summary: Progressives whitewash the Biden nominee's past and the Soviet reality that she and I lived.. I agree with your editorial "A Banking Regulator Who Hates Banks" (Oct. 25) that the Senate should not defer to the president regarding his pick for the office of comptroller of currency, Saule Omarova. As a fellow female immigrant from the former U.S.S.R., I oppose her nomination not out of misogyny or xenophobia but because I know that progressives are whitewashing Ms. Omarova's past and the Soviet reality that she, I and millions of others lived.

title: Reversing U.S. Progress in Jerusalem Policy
summary: The Palestinian Authority has given no sign that it would behave any better than the Jordanians did in control of eastern Jerusalem.. It is common knowledge that the Biden administration is intent on reversing President Trump's accomplishments. Yet one must wonder what the Palestinian Authority has done to deserve so much consideration ("Blinken Seems Intent on Sparking a Crisis Over Jerusalem" by Eugene Kontorovich, op-ed, Oct. 26).

title: What Pelosi Can Learn From Newton and JFK
summary: The third law of motion applies to tax policy, too.. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi estimates she can raise $200 billion to $250 billion in a decade by taxing unrealized capital gains ("The Democrats' Wealth-Tax Mirage," Review & Outlook, Oct. 26). She should take a course in physics. Sir Isaac Newton's Third Law of Motion-every action has an equal and opposite reaction-applies to tax policy, too. The government will spend billions ramping up the IRS's capability to track down those gains, while the targets themselves will be putting into motion the means to avoid the levies.

title: Remember Pastel Train Sets For Girls? Most People Don't
summary: The concept was a flop.. "Toy Brands Take On Bias" (Business News, Oct. 25) made me think of Lionel Corp., which in 1957 introduced a pastel train set for girls. The thinking at the time appeared to be that selling toy trains just to boys missed half of the potential market.

title: AIG Third-Quarter Profit Jumps on Insurance Sales, Higher Premiums
summary: The insurer's 2020 results were depressed by shutdowns related to the Covid-19 pandemic. American International Group Inc. reported strong improvement in third-quarter profit, as it sold more property-casualty insurance at higher premium rates.

title: Uber Reaches Income Milestone as Rides Recover, Delivery Grows
summary: The ride-hailing company recorded its first-ever adjusted profit last quarter. Uber Technologies Inc. achieved an important measure of profitability for the first time since its inception more than a decade ago, helped by a recovery in its rides business and the continued strength of its food-delivery unit.

title: 'Spencer': Stewart Reigns, Drama Drains
summary: Kristen Stewart stars as Diana, Princess of Wales, in Pablo Larraín's gloomy biopic. The distributors missed a Halloween opening by a week, but if you're still in the market for gothic horror "Spencer" may do the trick. It won't do, though, if you're looking for fresh insights into Diana, Princess of Wales, or even an absorbing rehash of one of the most rehashed stories ever. That's not to minimize the achievement of Kristen Stewart, who portrays the former Diana Spencer as a woman possessed by outer demons as well as inner ones. The problem is the dramatic vacuum, or suffocating bell jar, in which her performance plays out. Pablo Larraín's film, written by Steven Knight, calls itself a "fable from a true tragedy." It might also be called a fever dream, a surreal nightmare, a reductio ad tedium or just an inherently limiting concept that slowly but inexorably squeezes the life out of itself.

title: 'Eternals' Review: Heroic Characters, Hectic Story
summary: Millennia-old Eternals try to save Earth and its mortal inhabitants from the evil Deviants in Chloé Zhao's star-studded Marvel movie. 'Eternals" answers a question of cosmic proportions, as befits a Marvel release with a whole new cast of supercharacters. The question is how well Chloé Zhao, a singularly gifted filmmaker ("Nomadland") accustomed to working on a modest scale, was able to do as the director and co-writer of a superexpensive, supercomplicated and superlong action adventure.

title: Nuclear Advocates Say More Reactors Will Aid Renewables
summary: Critics say solar and wind are cheaper and less risky; nuclear supporters point to its reliability. The head of the United Nations' atomic energy watchdog touted nuclear power's virtues as a complement to wind and solar-energy sources that are getting more airtime at the U.N. climate summit in Glasgow.

title: Inflation Debate Hangs Over Stock Market's Record Run
summary: Some investors think the Federal Reserve will be forced to swiftly raise rates next year to rein in inflation and keep the economy stable. title: 'Dexter: New Blood' Review: Fresh Meat, Stale Story
summary: The vigilante serial killer played by Michael C. Hall returns to TV, with a reformed mindset and a new identity. If Dexter Morgan were in a 12-step program he'd be calling himself a "recovering" serial killer, at least when we first see him in "Dexter: New Blood." It's been 10 years (in TV time) since the forensics specialist and homicidal maniac played by Michael C. Hall stopped killing other homicidal maniacs. His life is good in upstate Iron Lake, N.Y. He lives in a cabin in the woods, raises goats, chops firewood, ice fishes and wears overalls. Under an alias, Jimmy Lindsay, he even has some pursuits that test his "sobriety" on a regular basis: Selling guns in the local sports shop. Putting up with obnoxious customers. And sharpening knives and cleavers for the local butcher. "You're a life saver, Jimmy," says Gig (David J. Curtis) with gratitude, and no end of unintentional irony.

title: How Youngkin Kept Trump at Arm's Length, but on His Side

title: Biden's Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate Divides U.S. Companies
summary: Some executives say requirements simplify their roles, while others raise concerns about costs and administrative hurdles. title: Bed Bath & Beyond Names Its First Chief Customer Officer
summary: The new position combines digital and brand roles, including customer support and user experience. Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. has named Rafeh Masood as its chief customer officer, a new role for the company.

title: 2021 McLaren 765LT: An Extreme Supercar, Now Faster and Lighter
summary: A more powerful variant of McLaren's 720S, the 765LT is one of the only street-legal internal combustion cars that keeps pace with the Tesla Model S Plaid. DUE TO THE periodic arrival of fantasy automobiles at my house, I am legend with the kids in the neighborhood. But even these veteran trainspotters were unprepared for the arrival of the coral-orange metallic McLaren 765LT Coupe. I watched their impressionable minds and mercenary hearts go kablooey at the sight. I felt like I was contributing to the delinquency of minors.

title: Three by Three (Friday Crossword, November 5)

summary: Trade gap was also affected by a sharp decline in U.S. exports. The U.S. trade deficit widened in September to $80.9 billion, a record, driven by climbing demand for capital goods like computers and electric equipment and industrial supplies that have been soaring in cost as global supply chains remain snarled.

title: Ex-Rivian Executive's Discrimination Suit Airs Questions About Business Plans as IPO Looms
summary: Former sales executive at electric-truck startup, which is seeking a valuation of more than $60 billion, says her concerns were ignored and she faced gender discrimination. title: U.K. Rate-Decision Surprise Ripples Across Global Bond Markets

title: Wheat Prices Jump, Signaling More Food Inflation
summary: Drought scorched the spring crop and threatens winter wheat. A poor harvest of spring wheat and concern over the winter crop have pushed prices for the grain to their highest levels in years and signal more food inflation ahead.

title: Gym Franchises Still Face Cash Crunch Even as Pandemic Abates
summary: While customers are slowly returning, some gyms are still running low on cash and carry elevated debt loads. 24 Hour Fitness Worldwide, Inc. and Equinox Holdings Inc. are pursuing out-of-the-box ways to raise cash from investors, as the gym franchises manage through a prolonged downturn catalyzed by the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: The Best Commuter Bags for Hybrid Work, When Your Load Is 10 Pounds Heavier
summary: From gym shoes and chargers to books, cutlery and laptops, workers without permanent desks now carry a lot more back and forth each day. Here, our five top picks to schlep it all.. As workers trickle back into offices that, in many cases, now consist of unassigned, socially distanced "hot desks," they're confronting more than a sense of dislocation. Namely the realization of how much they once relied on their under-desk filing cabinets to stash spare gym shoes, cutlery, chargers, mugs, water bottles and laptops overnight.

summary: Tie-up gives Google's cloud arm a prize client in financial services. Alphabet Inc.'s Google has invested $1 billion in futures-exchange giant CME Group Inc. and struck a deal to move the company's core trading systems to the cloud.

title: China, India and Other Developing Nations Seek $1.3 Trillion a Year in Climate Finance
summary: Request is made in paper presented at COP26 summit; richer countries say they aren't ready to pledge beyond 2025. GLASGOW-Most of the world's developing countries have backed a demand for wealthy nations to channel at least $1.3 trillion in climate finance to them annually starting in 2030, the opening salvo in one of the most contentious negotiating topics at the COP26 climate summit.

title: Finding Dignity and Excellence in the Great Books
summary: Far from being elitist, a college curriculum focused on the Western classics can open a new world for students of all backgrounds. In 1985, a few days before my 12th birthday, I left the Dominican Republic for New York City. The flight was only three and half hours, but the distance I traveled that day was in many ways incalculable. I didn't speak English and had never even been close to an airplane. The city that greeted me and my older brother was the menacing New York of the 1980s, and like many other Dominican immigrants, we arrived poor, disoriented and with little notion of what would happen next.

title: Sociologist Pioneered Focus Groups for Marketers
summary: Mimi Levin Lieber, who has died at age 93, delved inside customer's heads and later founded a nonprofit to teach young children to read. As a sociology student at the University of Chicago in the late 1940s, Mimi Levin skimped on studying but was good at making friends and taking tests. One other talent she discovered was interviewing people for research projects.

title: Bond Markets Flash Turmoil, and No One Else Much Cares
summary: The vast infusion of money by governments and central banks into the economy may have anesthetized investors. Investors have jolted government bond markets in the past month as they reassess what will happen to the basic cost of money that underpins the financial system.

summary: Funding for a carbon-free economy is infinite if there's a revenue stream, says Bank of America's Brian Moynihan. The world needs $4 trillion a year to transition to a carbon-free economy.

title: OPEC, Russia Stick to Gradual Oil Production Boost
summary: Producers reject U.S. pressure to boost output faster and ease prices. OPEC and a group of Russia-led producers agreed to keep to their gradual, monthly increase in oil output, deciding to boost production by 400,000 barrels a day next month and rebuffing stepped-up pressure from the U.S. to boost output and ease prices.

title: God's Universe Beats Mark Zuckerberg's Metaverse
summary: The Facebook chief's loveless high-tech fantasy world is a curse, not a blessing.. It's Mark Zuckerberg's "metaverse," we're just living in it. Or so he hopes. The founder of Facebook , now renamed Meta, "has long imagined a virtual world where people work, play and interact," this newspaper recently reported. The company will throw billions of dollars, thousands of workers and years of effort at creating a new digital reality.

title: Today's Historic Summit Agreements Don't Have Much of a Future
summary: Whether it's COP26, the G-7, or the G-20, few of the politicians signing deals have the mandate to do so.. President Biden hightailed it out of the COP26 climate confab in Glasgow before the returns from Tuesday's U.S. elections were in, and just as well. Talk about an embarrassment-for the entire global-summit-industrial complex as much as for Mr. Biden personally or his party back home.

title: More Small Businesses Than Ever Raising Compensation
summary: The latest NFIB employment report shows a historic worker shortage beginning to ease.. A record number of U.S. small firms raised compensation last month, and a record number plan to lift wages in the coming months. That's according to the latest monthly employment report from the National Federation of Independent Business, due out later today. Workers will find out whether the compensation increases will exceed inflation and therefore allow employees to enjoy real wage gains.

title: If We Upgrade Our Smartphones, Why Not Our Bread?
summary: It's high time we create more buzz around new releases of other essential items like floss, shovels and pajamas. Smartphone upgrades are a constant, and costly, fact of modern life. Cameras perennially get better; battery life incrementally improves; phones become less likely to fail if dropped on the pavement or submerged in Jägermeister. Above all, these upgrades never fail to create buzz. Hyperventilating techies proclaim that the millennium has arrived, even while battling over which models are actually worth upgrading to compared with cheaper alternatives.

title: Nikola Set to Pay $125 Million to Settle SEC Investigation
summary: Electric-truck startup says it will seek reimbursement for the penalty from its founder, Trevor Milton, who was indicted on fraud charges in July. WASHINGTON-Electric-truck startup Nikola Corp. will likely pay $125 million to settle a regulatory investigation into allegedly misleading statements made by its founder and former executive chairman.

title: Why Your Car Will Become Even More Like an iPhone
summary: Doug Field, who left Apple for Ford in September, talks about automation, Detroit vs. Silicon Valley and the way that custom subscriptions will remake the auto industry. Author

title: Drug Industry Gets Mild Treatment From Congress
summary: Measures agreed to among congressional Democrats this week to lower prescription-drug costs for seniors could have been far more draconian. Wall Street shouldn't be thrilled about this week's agreement among Democrats on a plan to lower the cost of prescription drugs. But it removes the threat of something that would be far more damaging to pharmaceutical investors.

title: In a Deal Desert, Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Keeps Buying Itself
summary: Analysts expect the Omaha conglomerate's stock repurchases to hold steady in the third quarter. Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. didn't pull the trigger on any major acquisitions this past quarter-unless you count the company's own shares.

title: Election Results 2021: Who Won, From Virginia to New Jersey
summary: New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy held on to his office, while Republican Glenn Youngkin won Virginia governor race. A Republican won the Virginia governor race Tuesday, and Democrat Phil Murphy was re-elected New Jersey governor Wednesday evening. Both races were close and turnout was high, especially for an election without national races. Boston voters elected for the first time a woman and a person of color to lead Massachusetts' capital, while New York City elected the city's second Black mayor.

title: Cathie Wood Sells Chunk of Zillow Stock a Day After Buying the Dip
summary: Real-estate company's stock has lost nearly half its value this year. Fund manager Cathie Wood's flagship exchange-traded fund sold a chunk of its holdings in Zillow Group Inc . on Wednesday as the stock plunged, a day after the fund had bought more shares in the real-estate company.

title: Manhattan Apartment of Suzy Welch, Widow of GE's Jack Welch, Lists for $25 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. Suzy Welch, the widow of former General Electric Co. Chairman and CEO Jack Welch, is listing the couple's New York City apartment for $25 million.

title: Who Wants to Be GM of the New York Mets?
summary: No, seriously, they're looking. Top candidates are proving elusive.. OK, fine. I'll be the general manager of the New York Mets. If no one wants the job, I'll sign up. I'll do it for $4 million, or better yet, $9 million, plus three new bicycles, and all the coffee cake I can eat. You're welcome, New York.

title: Credit Suisse Plans a Cultural Revolution
summary: Getting the right balance between risk management and entrepreneurial spirit won't be easy for the bank's new chairman. António Horta-Osório's planned overhaul of Credit Suisse is more cultural than structural. That puts the onus on his management skills to bring the crisis-prone Swiss bank back into line with more successful peer UBS.

title: Fafsa May Be Tricky This Year for College Students and Parents
summary: The economic environment, plus certain rules changes, make it crucial that families understand the process. It is Fafsa time again, when parents and students fill out the required financial disclosure for college financial aid. For some parents, the economic environment-as well as various changes in the rules-makes it especially important that they understand the process this year.

title: Number Puzzles (Saturday, November 6)
VW CEO Makes EV Pledge as Labor Leaders Criticize Pace of Transition
summary: CEO Herbert Diess and labor leaders also clash over chip crisis. BERLIN-Volkswagen AG Chief Executive Herbert Diess pledged to build a future electric vehicle at the company's flagship German plant in a bid to head off an escalating conflict with VW's powerful labor leaders that has thrust the firm's future into uncertainty.

title: Padma Lakshmi, Host of 'Taste the Nation,' on Great Food Towns and 'Filthy' TV Shows
summary: After months of lockdown, the 'Top Chef' veteran is back to feeding her wanderlust. Here, she tells us about her favorite U.S. city, what to buy at Muji and where to roller skate in Paris.. PADMA LAKSHMI first boarded a plane at age 4 to make a solo trans-Atlantic journey from New Delhi to New York to reunite with her mother. Travel continued to shape her life and career as an international model who hosted a variety show while living in Italy-long before she landed the gig as an itinerant host of Bravo's "Top Chef."

title: Fix Burnout-Without Blowing Up Your Life
summary: After an intense 20 months of pandemic work and life, many are reaching a breaking point. Here's how to retake control.. The emails are piling up, unread. Deadlines are blown. Once jovial video calls are now tense. You suspect burnout.

title: Why Children Learn Better Than Adults
summary: In a 'learning trap' experiment, adults leap faster to conclusions while children explore and gather more information. Psychologist Alison Gopnik explores new discoveries in the science of human nature. Read previous columns here.

title: How Small Businesses Can Cultivate Loyalty Amid the Great Resignation
summary: Being transparent, flexible and generous are three key ingredients to reducing turnover. Candace Nelson, a pastry chef and former investment banker, is co-founder of the cupcake bakery chain Sprinkles. She also is co-founder of CN2 Ventures, which invests in and incubates new business ventures.

title: Give Your Earlobes A Workout This Season
summary: Long, sparkly earrings jazz up serious formalwear and playful cocktail dresses alike.. As festivities go back into full swing, add some personality to your look with earrings that dangle and dazzle. Layering on the sparkle is fitting after months of quiet dressing. A full suite of jewelry is no longer needed to make a statement, as this season's earrings speak volumes on their own. Pair Great Gatsby-esque earrings with an embellished Miu Miu dress to channel your inner Daisy Buchanan, or go the glam Debbie Harry route with a glittering Celine by Hedi Slimane dress and Isabel Marant oversize crystal fringe earrings. The sleek tailoring of black evening jackets from Chanel, Dolce & Gabbana and Saint Laurent by Anthony Vaccarello recall the striking style of fashion icon Tina Chow when matched with earrings of cascading crystals and luminous pearls. From suiting to dresses, any outfit benefits from the polishing touch of a well-chosen statement earring. -Kevin Huynh

title: Tesla, Moderna, Zillow, Qualcomm, Qorvo: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Moderna shares sank on a reduced revenue outlook; Qualcomm gained on record quarterly sales. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite opened higher, putting them on course to extend gains that followed the Federal Reserve's move to scale back its bond purchases. Here's what we're watching in Thursday's trading:

title: Hertz Will Have to Wait for Teslas, Just Like Other Buyers
summary: Companies in talks over timing of deliveries for 100,000 Tesla order. Tesla Inc. and Hertz Global Holdings Inc. are negotiating over how quickly Hertz will receive deliveries from a bulk order of 100,000 Tesla electric cars for its rental fleet, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: COP26 Deals Aim to Limit Coal, Oil and Natural-Gas Development
summary: As governments push for a U.N. deal to cut emissions, some have sought out like-minded partners for smaller agreements. GLASGOW-Dozens of countries agreed to stop funding new coal-fired power plants, a deal that brings some previous holdouts like Poland and Vietnam aboard a growing coalition of countries vowing to wean their economies off the fossil fuel.

title: Merck Covid-19 Pill Cleared for Use in U.K., Its First Authorization
summary: U.S. is also expected to authorize molnupiravir, which has been found to reduce the risk of hospitalization, in coming months. U.K. health regulators cleared a Covid-19 drug developed by Merck & Co. with partner Ridgeback Biotherapeutics LP, becoming the first country to authorize the pill that can be taken at home and has been shown to reduce death and hospitalization in higher-risk patients.

title: Unemployment Claims Extend Drop
summary: Worker filings for unemployment benefits fell to 269,000 last week. Worker filings for unemployment benefits continued their steady downward march as they approached levels last seen before the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The New Rules of Tidying Up
summary: It's time to shove the stuff you're with. If you are fortunate enough to have a job you can do remotely, you've probably spent more time in your home surrounded by and interacting with your stuff than you ever have before. Your feelings about your things range from "I love that couch. I live on that couch. Mmmmm...couch," to "Did I get these pants at the swap area at the dump?"

title: Oh, the Places Parents Will Go! (Once the Kids Are Vaccinated)
summary: Resume Subscription. Families who have been waiting for months to get their children vaccinated say they are thrilled at the chance to finally get their pre-pandemic lives back.

title: Credit Suisse Carries Out Sweeping Post-Archegos Overhaul
summary: Swiss bank says its central mission will be catering to the world's rich. Credit Suisse Group AG will slash ties with hedge funds and focus on its core business of catering to the global rich, part of a reorganization that aims to prevent a repeat of the client blowups and regulatory penalties that have rocked the bank.

title: TikTok Is Now on TV Screens. Is It Still TikTok?
summary: Amazon launched a TikTok app made for TV screens. But TVs weren't made for TikTok's vertical videos, infinite scrolling and comment culture.. TikTok, already a fixture on many smartphones, is moving to the biggest screen in the home: the television set.

title: Novartis to Sell Roche Stake for $20.7 Billion
summary: Share sale, which ends unusual entanglement of Swiss drug giants, hands Novartis a war chest for deals. Novartis AG said it would sell its stake in Roche Holding AG back to its crosstown rival for $20.7 billion, bringing an end to the unusual, decadeslong entanglement of the two Swiss drug giants.

title: Covid-19 Lockdowns Ripple Across China
summary: Resume Subscription. For more than a year, residents living in a remote border town have been China's foot soldiers in the battle against the coronavirus, enduring lockdown after lockdown to shield the rest of the country from contagion.

title: Looking for a Less Thrilling Ride Than Tesla? Try a Good Ole' Toyota
summary: The global chip famine actually ended up bringing in big money for the world's most profitable auto maker. The chip shortage is bringing more profit to the world's most profitable auto maker. The challenge for Toyota is how to navigate a future that is increasingly electric.

title: Chinese Developer Stocks Endure New Selloff as Kaisa Hits Record Low
summary: Wealth-management product guaranteed by Kaisa misses payment. Chinese developers' stocks came under renewed pressure Thursday, with shares in Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd. , one of the industry's biggest borrowers in international bond markets, sliding to record lows.

title: Epstein's Accusers Seek Justice at Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
summary: Prosecutors, lawyers, accusers have pushed on various legal fronts since financier's 2019 death. When Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in August 2019 while awaiting trial on allegations that he sexually abused dozens of underage girls, some of his accusers said they feared they would never get closure.

title: Etsy Could Be In for a Pleasant Holiday Surprise
summary: Online marketplace known for handmade and vintage goods can look forward to a happier holiday season than will traditional retailers. There is a fair chance toys and gifts will be stuck in container ships this holiday season. That's bad news for nearly everyone-but not for Etsy .

title: Has the NBA's Scoring Bubble Burst?
summary: For the first time since the 3-point revolution began, NBA offenses have gotten worse this season.. They couldn't have known this when they were coming into the NBA, but Luka Doncic and Trae Young happened to enter the league at a curious stage in the evolution of basketball.

title: Google Allows Alternate In-App Payment Options in South Korea, Though Familiar Fees Remain
summary: App developers can use payment services other than Google's, but still face commissions. SEOUL- Alphabet Inc.'s Google plans to continue charging South Korean app developers a service fee for in-app purchases, even as users for the first time globally can choose to use third-party payment platforms rather than Google's.

title: Toyota Profit Zooms Past Chip Shortage
summary: Car maker expects sales and profit to rebound in the year ending March 2022. Toyota Motor Corp. shrugged off the effects of a semiconductor shortage and reported higher profit in the most recent quarter as well as an improved forecast for the full fiscal year.

title: Military Coups in Africa at Highest Level Since End of Colonialism
summary: Attempted or successful coups in Africa are occurring more frequently as democratic states buckle under pressure from Covid-19. On the day before launching the coup that halted Sudan's democratic transition last month, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan made a string of daring geopolitical moves. He reassured Jeffrey Feltman, the U.S. envoy to Sudan, that he didn't intend to seize power. Then he boarded a jet to Egypt for secret talks to ensure his plot would have regional support.

title: Pregnant Women Doubting Vaccine Worry Doctors
summary: Some expectant mothers say they believe the risks of getting vaccinated outweigh the benefits, presenting a challenge to health authorities. Jaime Francis is avoiding all medication during her pregnancy, including Covid-19 vaccines.

title: North Korea Can Make More Uranium for Nuclear Bombs Than Previously Thought
summary: The Kim regime is making a fraction of potential fissile material that could be used for bomb, according to new research based on satellite-imagery analysis. SEOUL-North Korea has the capacity to make more base ingredients for nuclear bombs than previously believed, according to new research, suggesting the Kim Jong Un regime possesses the potential to accelerate the earliest stages of production.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy Wins Tight Election Race
summary: Democrat narrowly beat Jack Ciattarelli to become first in party to win re-election in the state since 1977. Democratic New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy held on to his office in a race that ended up much closer than the polls had suggested before Election Day.

title: House Democrats Include Provisions Protecting Immigrants
summary: Temporary work authorization for immigrants would be included in $1.85 trillion healthcare, education and climate bill; proposal's fate in Senate is uncertain. WASHINGTON-House Democrats included new protections for immigrants in the country illegally in the revised text of their social spending and climate bill released Wednesday, after several previous proposals hit a dead end in the Senate.

title: MGM Plans to Sell Mirage Operations in Las Vegas
summary: Expected deal is the latest transaction by the casino operator as it focuses more on new business areas like sports betting. MGM Resorts International said it would sell its operations of The Mirage to another operator, part of a rash of deals that are changing the hands of ownership on the Las Vegas Strip.
